projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE FRENCH ALPHABETH, TEACHING IN A VERY SHORT TIME, BY a mo≈øt ea≈øie way, to pronounce French naturally, to reade it perfectly, to write it truely, and to ≈øpeake it accordingly.

p.hi: Together vvith THE TREASVRE OF THE French toung, conteyning the rare≈øt Sentences, Pouerbes, Parables, Similies, Apothegmes, and Golden ≈øayings, of the mo≈øt excellent French Authours, as vvell Potes as Orators.

div.head: A TRES-ILLVSTRE, ET TRES-HEROIQVE LE SIEVR HENRY WALLOPPE Cheualier, & Thre≈øorier General de ≈øa Sereni≈ø≈øime Maie≈øt√© en Irlande.
div.p:
MONSIEVR, le principal but, ou doibuent vi≈øer toutes nos Actions, e≈øt d'auoir plus d'e≈øgard au bien publicq, qu'√† no≈øtre propre vtilit√©. Et combieÃÑ que tous ne ≈øoyent ≈øuffi≈øans de proffiter en cho≈øes grandes, ils ne doibuent neantmoins auoir honte de s'employer es petites. Car comme il n'y a membre, qui, pour quelque excellence qu'il pui≈ø≈øe auoir, ne paye tribut de ≈øeruitude au corps, dont il e≈øt vne partie: au≈ø≈øin'y a il nul (s'il n'e≈øt du tout mon≈øtre en nature) qui ne vueille ou doibue procurer, en tout ce qui luy ≈øera po≈ø≈øible, l'aduancemeÃÑt du Corps dela Republicque, dont luy me≈øme
e≈øt vn membre. A ce≈øte cau≈øe, encore que le flambeau ardant de la guerre ciuile, qui maintenant con≈øume no≈øtre pauure France, ait tellement bru≈øl√© les ai≈øles de mes E≈øtudes, & rompu le col a ma fortune, qu'il m'a du tout de≈ørob√© les moyeÃÑs de luy faire quelque boÃÑ ≈øeruice: toutesfois ie n'ay voulu viure du tout inutile, ≈øinoÃÑ √† ma patrie, au moins a ceux, qui au lieu d'icelle m'ont aym√©, embra≈ø≈ø√©, & chery. E≈øtant doncq refugi√© a l'ombre fauorable du Sceptre de fa Sereni≈ø≈øime Maie≈øt√©, qui e≈øt le vray port de retraicte, & A≈øyle a≈ø≈øeur√© de ceux, qui fai≈øans profe≈ø≈øion de l'Euangile, ≈øouffrent ores per≈øecution ≈øoubs la Tyrannie de l'Antechri≈øt, i'ay ta≈øch√©, de tout mon pouuoir, de faire en ≈øorte par mes labeurs, que ce≈øte Noble Nation, qui maintenant nous ≈øert de mere & de nourrice, peu≈øt tirer quelque proffit d'iceux, afin
que par ce moyeÃÑ ie peu≈ø≈øe euiter le vice enorme de l'ingratitude, vice autant dete≈øtable, que l'ho≈øpitalit√©, & large≈ø≈øe e≈øt louable. Or entre toutes les belles, & rares vertus, dont la Noble≈ø≈øe Angloi≈øe ≈øe rend tant renomm√©e par tout le monde, admir√©e des E≈øtrangiers, & honor√©e en ≈øon pa√Øs, e≈øt l'E≈øtude des bonnes lettres, & cognoi≈ø≈øance des langues, qui leur ≈øont ≈øi familieres & communes, qu'il s'en trouue peu parmy eux, non ≈øeulement entre les Seigneurs, & Gentils-hommes, qui n'en parlent trois ou quatre pour le moins, mais au≈ø≈øi entre les Dames, & Damoi≈øelles, exercice veritablement louable, par lequel toute
vertu s'honore & ≈øe rend immortelle, & ≈øans lequel nulle autre n'e≈øt parfait, n'y digne d'e≈øtre aucunement e≈øtim√©. Or c'e≈øt ce qui, outre la ≈øinguliere affection, que naturalement ils portent aux e≈øtrangers, & la grande courtoi≈øie, dont ils ont accou≈øtum√© de les traicter, leur fait faire tant d'e≈øtat des Fran√ßois, ≈øi bien qu'il y en a fort peu, qui n'en ait vn auec ≈øoy. Ce qui m'a e≈ømeu, voyant no≈øtre Nation leur e≈øtre tant redeuable, de leur faire (pour l'obligatioÃÑ de moÃÑ particulier) ce petit Traict√©, que i'ay intitul√© The French Alphabeth, par lequel i'e≈øpere qu'ils trouueroÃÑt cy apres la langue Fran√ßoi≈øe au≈ø≈øi ai≈ø√©e √† pronoÃÑcer, que cy deuant ils l'e≈øtimoyeÃÑt mal ai≈ø√©e & difficile. le m'en raporte neantmoins (Mon≈øieur) a ce meur & ≈øain iugemeÃÑt, dont auec la balaÃÑce de la rai≈øon, vous auez accou≈øtum√© de pe≈øer iu≈øtement de toutes cho≈øes, vous, dy-ie, √† qui la langue Fran√ßoi≈øe e≈øt au≈ø≈øi naturelle, que la vo≈øtre propre. C'e≈øt pourquoy ie preÃÑs la hardie≈ø≈øe de luy faire voir le iour ≈øoubs vo≈øtre Nom, m'a≈ø≈øeurant que ≈øi vous daignez le couurir du manteau de vo≈øtre accou≈øtum√©e faueur, & le preÃÑdre en vo≈øtre protectioÃÑ, les griffes de l'enuie ne le pourront aucunemeÃÑt offencer. Et ce qui m'a e≈ømeu de le vous dedier plu≈øto≈øt qu'a nul autre, e≈øt
que , des il y a trois ans pa≈ø≈øez, que i'eu ce≈øt hoÃÑneur d'e≈øtre cogneu de vous, &
que de vo≈øtre grace il vous pleut me faire taÃÑt de faueur de me doÃÑner acc√©s en vo≈øtre mai≈øon, par le moyen de Mon≈øieur HENRY WALLOPPE vo≈øtre fils ai≈øn√©,
qui ≈øuyuant les glorieu≈øes traces de vos hero√Øques vertus, ≈øe fait par les belles parties, qui ≈øont en luy, non ≈øeulement aymer d'vn chacun, mais au≈ø≈øi donne e≈øperance √† tous de produire, des ≈øouaues fleurs du Prin temps de ≈øa douce ieune≈ø≈øe, de beaux, & ≈øauoureux fruicts de la vertu, √† l'honneur, & gloire de Dieu, au ≈øeruice loyal de ≈øon Prince, & au bien, & proffit de ≈øa patrie, ie vey reluyre en vous tant d'e≈øtincelles de l'Ancienne, & vraye Noble≈ø≈øe, & depuis en ay de plus en plus remarqu√© taÃÑt d'effects,
que i'ay pen≈ø√© ne luy pouuoir choi≈øir plus fauorable parrain. Ie vous ≈øupplie donc affectueu≈øement de l'auoir pour aggreable, & luy faire au≈ø≈øi bon accueil,
que tre≈ø-humblement ie le vous pre≈øente, dont ie ne fay aucune doubte, veu qu'entre les vertus, qui vous font re≈øpecter de tous en general, & honorer d'vn chacun en particulier, la ≈øinguliere douceur, & man≈øuetude, qui vous accompagne, & vous rend ≈øi affectionn√© aux E≈øtrangers, & ≈øpecialement aux Fran√ßois, m'en a≈ø≈øeure. Et en ce≈øt endroit, ie prieray Dieu.

closer.salute: MOn≈øieur, vous donner en ≈øant√© tre≈ø-heureu≈øe, & longue vie.
closer.signed: Vo≈øtre tre≈ø-humble, & tre≈ø-affectionn√© ≈øeruiteur. G. Delamothe N.

lg.head: QVATRAIN.
lg.l: Quand Lache≈øis ourdit le fil de vo≈øtre vie,
Clotho, ≈øoubs vo≈øtre Nom, chantoit de vous ain≈øi:
Il ira triumphant du Temps, & de l'Enuie,
Puis que L'HONEVR L'APPVYE, & le maintient au≈ø≈øi.

lg.head: SONNET ACROSTICHE.
lg.l: Honeur fils des Vertus, & frere de Louange,
E≈øt nourry du Nectar, qui s'influe des cieux:
N√© de parens diuins, il vit entre les Dieux,
Rendant diuin celuy, qui ≈øoubs ≈øon bras ≈øe range.
Ya-til rien plus grand? Il fait (merueille e≈øtrange)
Wiure apres le trepas les hommes vertueux;
Woire il les pou≈ø≈øe encor, d'vn vol audacieux,
Ains leur Soleil couch√©, d'Albion iu≈øqu'au Gange.
Lhomme e≈øt trois fois heureux, qui l'e≈ølit pour appuy.
Le Temps, qui ≈øappe tout, n'a de pouuoir ≈øur luy,
Ores qu'il ≈øoit tou≈øiours a≈ø≈øailly de l'Enuie.
Partant HENRY WALLOPPE e≈øt ≈øeur coÃÑtre le Temps,
Puis que L'HONEVR L'APPVYE, & bienheuraÃÑt ≈øes ans.

div.head: AN EPISTLE TO THE READER, VVARNING HIM OF THE MEthode that he ought to keepe in learning the French-toung.

p.hi: THe fir≈øt and chiefe≈øt degree of learning (gentle Reader) is a mutuall loue and agreement, betweene him that doth teach, and him that doth learne: I hope that both are both in you and me. In you, becau≈øe you ≈øeeke for me, and hauing found me, keepe me in your companie, and delight to talke with me. In me, becau≈øe I haue with very great payne and care, compiled this booke, onely for you, I spare no tyme to doe you good, and preferre your furtheraunce before myne owne ≈øtudies. But before we goe any further, it is my duety to teach you faithfully, the methode that you ought to keepe, if you will ≈øhortly reape the fruite of your hope, and gather the ≈øweet premi≈ø≈øes of

my liberall promi≈øe: you being then ≈øo de≈øirous to be taught of me, as I am willing to in≈øtruct you, I doe not doubt, but you will be ≈øo carefull to ob≈øerue both my methode and my rules, ≈øo warie to performe the ≈øame, and ≈øo constant to continue in them, as I haue bene painefull and earne≈øt to inuent them, diligent to pre≈øcribe, and am willing to further you by them. They be fewe, and ≈øo the more ea≈øie to learne, and le≈ø≈øe hard to practi≈øe: and thus much for our mutuall loue. And as for the other, you meane to learne quickly, and I purpo≈øe to teach you ≈øpeedely, and ≈øo we agree. But as I haue taken great paynes in gathering the≈øe rules, ≈øo you mu≈øt ≈øpare no labour in learning them, and ≈øo we ≈øhall agree to. For do not thinke that my booke is able by him≈øelf to make you a good FreÃÑchmaÃÑ, except for your part you will play the diligent ≈øtudient, as for it, it will teach you faithfully. There is nothing though neuer ≈øo ea≈øie if one goe vnwillingly about it, and be≈øides be not well taught, but he ≈øhall finde it mo≈øt hard. There is nothing though neuer ≈øo hard, if one go with a de≈øire to it, an earne≈øt labour about it, v≈øe diligeÃÑce in it, and be well taught, but is quickly learned, and founde mo≈øt ea≈øie. Therefore if you will willingly ob≈øerue my rules, and carefully keepe my methode, I doe not doubt, but you ≈øhall finde the FreÃÑch toung ≈øo ea≈øie, as other before haue tried it hard: and ≈øhall receiue ≈øuch benefit thereby, that you wil neuer repeÃÑt to haue learned of me, nor I to haue taught you. For I hope that ≈øhortly you ≈øhall receiue the fruite of your hope, the profite of your labour, and
I thankes for the reward of my payne.

The fir≈øt thing I de≈øire you to ob≈øerue is, that you will vouch≈øafe to learne perfectly, and aboue all things both your letters and your ≈øyllables. Be not loth to ≈øpend three or foure dayes about them, for tho≈øe foure dayes will do you more profit, then foure monethes ≈øpent without the learning of them.

Secondly, wheÃÑ you haue them perfectly, begin to read, but before, ≈øpell foure or fiue times euery word, though neuer ≈øo ≈ømall, one after another: And for the beginning take but three or foure lines at once, or more or le≈ø≈øe according as your capacitie can reach, and your pacieÃÑce permit. And in your ≈øpelling & reading, let not pa≈ø≈øe any letter nor ≈øyllable, without bringing theÃÑ to the tryall of your rules, to know if either they mu≈øt be ≈øounded after the Engli≈øh fa≈øhion or no, what differeÃÑce there be betweene theÃÑ, what letter mu≈øt be pronouÃÑced & what not: and why it is pronouÃÑced or not. I haue ≈øpokeÃÑ of theÃÑ particularly, ≈øo that if you haue neede of any of theÃÑ, you ≈øhal finde them in their order, and the generall rules after.

Thirdly, wheÃÑ you can read truely, and pronouÃÑce perfectly, theÃÑ go about to Engli≈øh it, you haue in this booke the Engli≈øh tran≈ølation word for word, to teach it you. When you vnder≈øtand it, and are able to Engli≈øh it, theÃÑ copie out the French, and write it in ≈øome paper booke, the which you ≈øhall haue prouided for that purpo≈øe. Then after hauing ≈øhut your FreÃÑch Alphabeth, write vnder the French, the Engli≈øh that you can giue to it: that being done, conferre your tran≈ølation with your

booke, and amende your faultes if you haue committed any. After that lay away from you the French, and trye if you can put your Engli≈øh tran≈ølation into FreÃÑch againe. Continue this order for a moneth euery day, repeating three or foure tymes, both your letters and your ≈øyllables, & reading and Engli≈øhing as many times your old, from the beginning, till your later le≈ø≈øon: lea≈øt in learning the one, you ≈øhould forget the other, and be≈øides that, the old may be a helpe to the new. Being once able to read and pronounce perfectly with your rules two or three leaues of your booke at the mo≈øt, I can a≈ø≈øure you, that there is not any Frenche booke, though neuer ≈øo hard, but you ≈øhall be able to read and pronounce it as truely as can be wi≈øhed for. For in le≈ø≈øe then in a leafe of your booke, all your rules are to be ob≈øerued, three or foure tymes at lea≈øt. For there is no word but in it is one or two rules to be noted. This way will ≈øeeme to you at the beginning very hard, and ≈øo though it be more painefull then hard, it is in deede the harde≈øt of the French toung, except it be faithfully taught, and al≈øo diligently learned. But though in it ≈øelfe it is without teaching, not onely the harde≈øt, but al≈øo, as if it were impo≈ø≈øible to attaine, you ≈øhall finde it the mo≈øt ea≈øie≈øt, if you will learne, and be ruled by the≈øe rules.

Fourthly, when you know all the rules of your true pronounciation, and can exactly ob≈øerue them in reading, then go forward ≈øpeedely in your booke, and euery day tran≈ølate of it out of French into Engli≈øh, and out

of Engli≈øh into French, as much as you can, repeating often your old, lea≈øt you ≈øhould forget it. This is the only readie≈øt way to in≈øtruct you, not only in the right reading, and naturall pronounciation of the French toung, and in the perfect knowledge and vnderstanding of the ≈øame, but al≈øo to make you write it truely, and ≈øpeake it accordingly. Without chaunging of methode, keepe this order ≈øtill, not letting pa≈ø≈øe any day without learning ≈øome thing, and you ≈øhall finde, in le≈ø≈øe then fiue or ≈øixe weekes, your labour and diligence, afforde you ≈øuch profite and aduauncement, that you will wonder at it, and much greater then I dare promi≈øe you.

Furthermore when you are pretely furthered in it, get you acquainted, if it be po≈ø≈øible, with ≈øome French man, to the end you may practi≈øe with him, by dayly conference together, in ≈øpeech and talke, what you haue learned. And if you be in a place, where the Frenchmen haue a Church for them≈øelues, as they haue in London, get you a French Bible, or a new Testament, and euery day goe both to their Lecture and Sermons. The one will confirme and ≈øtrength your pronounciation, and the other to vnder≈øtand when one doth speake.

Finally, if you haue a de≈øire both to vnder≈øtand perfectly the hardest and mo≈øt eloquent French, and to ≈øpeake it naturally, you must prouide you ≈øome French Dictionarie, and the harde≈øt booke you can finde, then tran≈ølate it, after the maner that I haue pre≈øcribed

you before, or if you will not take the payne to tran≈ølate (though it be the ≈øurest and ≈øhorte≈øt way) read it diligently and picke out in ≈øome booke, both the harde≈øt wordes, and the be≈øt phra≈øes to ≈øerue your turne, either to ≈øpeake or to write, when you haue neede of.

div.p: But becau≈øe without Grammar it is almo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible to ≈øpeake perfectly, but with a very great labour, and long tract of tyme, if this my French-Alphabeth, whom I ≈øend you for an herbenger of my great loue, and good will I beare you, can finde any fauour at your handes; I will ≈øhortly ≈øent you a FRENCH TVTOR, that will teach you in ≈øo ≈øhort and ea≈øie way, as may be both, by the perfect knowledge of the partes of your ≈øpeeches and Syntaxe, not onely to speake perfectly, but al≈øo to know if one doth not ≈øpeake well, to reproue him when he doth ≈øpeake ill, and to teach him how to amend his bad ≈øpeeche, a thing which yet before hath neuer bene taught. The promi≈øe is great, but the performance ≈øhall not be le≈ø≈øe, if this be acceptable vnto you. If I ≈øatisfie you, I doe ≈øatisfie my ≈øelfe, de≈øiring the one, becau≈øe I wi≈øhe for the other. But if my wi≈øhes doe not aun≈øwere to your expectation, I pray you let your fauorable curte≈øie wa≈øhe my fault in the ≈øtreames of the good will I beare you: And in that deuotion. I bid you farewell.

div.head: AN ADVERTISEMENT to the Reader.
div.p: GEntle Readers, if there be any of you, that for your better furtherance in the French toung, ≈øhall be de≈øirous to be acquainted with the Authour of this booke, you ≈øhall heare of him, in Fleet≈øtreet beneath the conduit, at the ≈øigne of S. Iohn th'Euangeli≈øt, where this booke is to be ≈øold: or els in Paules Churchyard at the ≈øigne of the Helmet. And there you ≈øhall finde him very willing to ≈øhow you any fauour and curte≈øie he may: and mo≈øt ready to endeuour him≈øelfe to ≈øatisfie you, in all that can be po≈ø≈øible for him to do. And thus. Fare you well.

div.head: De la prononciation. Of the pronunciation.

list.label: Car vous ≈ø√ßauez (comme i'ay dit deuant) que de la prononciation des lettres, ≈øe fait la prononciation des ≈øyllabes: & de la prononciation des ≈øyllabes, ≈øe fait la prononciation des mots, & de la vraye prononciation des mots, ≈øe fait la vraye prononciation de la langue Fran√ßoi≈øe, & ain≈øi des autres: ≈øi bien qu'il faut tou≈øiours commencer par les lettres, & ne pa≈ø≈øer point outre qu'on ne les ait parfaictement.

item.hi: For you know (as I haue ≈øaid before) that of the pronunciation of the letters, is made the pronunciation of the ≈øyllables: and of the pronunciation of the ≈øyllables, is made the pronunciation of the wordes: and of the true pronunciation of the wordes, is made the true pronunciation of the French toung, and likewi≈øe of others: ≈øo that it behoueth alwayes to begin with the letters, and not to go any further, till one hath them perfectly,

que ce ≈øoit.

list.item: A Mute is a con≈øonant, which before an other con≈øonant, except before l and r is neuer pronounced, either in the beginning or in the midst, or the end, either of a word or of a ≈øyllable, as vous me faictes grand tort certes.

Il les faut prononcer bruler, m√©me, √©lire, touiours, m√©chant, √©chapper.

list.label: Vnze, a≈ø√ßauoir b c d f g p q s t x z.

item.hi: What is a Liquide?

list.item: It is very hard for the ≈øtrangers of the French toung, in their beginning, to pronounce e feminin, becau≈øe it is peculiar to the Frenchmen onely, ≈øo that the pronunciation thereof can not be learned, but in hearing them to ≈øound it. it is almo≈øt ≈øounded like e of the≈øe Engli≈øh wordes, able, table, po≈ø≈øible, amiable, all the difference is that the Engli≈øhmen do pronounce it as if it were before l, and they ≈ømoother it in their mouth, pre≈ø≈øing the palet with their toung, where contrariwi≈øe the Frenchmen do giue him his ≈øound after l, opening a litle their mouth

list.item: Except the plurall number of the nownes which do end their ≈øinguler nuÃÑber with e feminine, as cho≈øes, toutes, belles, &c. in the which e remaineth alwayes feminine, except the words of one ≈øyllable, as des, les, mes, ≈øes, tes, es, in the which e is neuter.

If fault done prononcer ≈øapiance, audiance, con≈øciance, &c.

item.hi: SIr, ≈øith that the pronunciation of the French tongue, and generally of all the other languages, con≈øi≈øteth in the pronunciation of the letters, but e≈øpecially of the vowels (becau≈øe that without them the con≈øonants cannot giue any ≈øound) and that there be vowels which giue voyce both to the ≈øyllables and to the words; and be≈øides that, we haue ≈øufficiently enough ≈øpoken of the ≈øame vowels; will not that ≈øuffi≈øe for the pronunciation of the French tongue, as well to reade well, as to ≈øpeake well?

list.label: Nenny. Car comme la prononciation de nos voyelles differe de la prononciation des vo≈øtres, au≈øsy la prononciation de nos Con≈øonantes e≈øt beaucoup differente de la vo≈øtre, qui fait que vo≈øtre langue, & la no≈øtre different tant en prononciation.

item.hi: No for≈øoth. For euen as the pronunciation of our vowelles differeth from the pronunciation of yours; ≈øo the pronunciation of our Con≈øonantes is much different from yours, the which thing cau≈øeth your toung and ours to differ ≈øo much in the pronunciation.

list.label: Il e≈øt donc de be≈øoing que vous ≈ø√ßachiez, comment nos con≈øonantes ≈øe prononcent, & que vous pui≈ø≈øiez di≈øcerner la difference qu'il y a entre la prononciation de nos con≈øonantes, & les vo≈øtres.

item.hi: Then it is needefull for you to know, how our con≈øonantes are pronounced, and di≈øcerne the true difference which is betweene the pronunciation of our con≈øonantes and yours.

list.label: I'ay apprins cela des le commencement, par les tables que vous en auez faictes en ce liure.

item.hi: I haue learned that euen from the beginning, by the tables that you haue made of them in this booke.

item.hi: It is the better. I am very glad of it:

list.label: Mais ie de≈øire ≈ø√ßauoir ≈øi vous ne les auez point oubliez. Car il les faut repeter tous les iours, & ≈øi ≈øouuent que vous les imprimiez en ≈øorte en vo≈øtre memoire, qu'elles vous ≈øoyent au≈ø≈øi ai≈ø√©es & familieres, que les vo≈øtres propres. Car ≈øans cela il e≈øt du tout impo≈ø≈øible que iamais vous prononciez bien, ≈øoit en li≈øant, ≈øoit en parlant, ny que vous pui≈ø≈øiez onc vrayement e≈øcrire.

item.hi: But I de≈øire to know if you haue not forgotten them. For you mu≈øt repete them euery day, and ≈øo often that you may imprint them in ≈øuch ≈øort into your memorie, that they be as ea≈øie and familiar vnto you, as your owne. For without them, it is impo≈ø≈øible that euer you can pronounce well, either reading or ≈øpeaking, nor that euer you ≈øhould write truely.

Seulement ie vous examineray; de ce en quoy elles ≈øont differentes des con≈øonantes Angloi≈øes.

Il y a vne autre rai≈øon qui vous

item.hi: It ≈øeemeth ≈øo vnto you, but they doe not ≈øpeake faster then the Engli≈øhmen: the Frenchmen thinke ≈øo much of the Engli≈øhmen, if they doe not vnder≈øtand their toung, as for me I thought ≈øo when I came vnto England, but I finde the contrarie now that I vnder≈øtand their toung: you ≈øhall finde it ≈øo, when you ≈øhall vnder≈øtand ours, and you ≈øhall finde very little difference, or none at all. list.label: faict pen≈øer que nous parlons ≈øi to≈øt, c'e≈øt que la plus grand part de nos mots ≈øont plus longs que les vo≈øtres, qui pre≈øque tous ≈øont d'vne≈øyllabe, ≈øi bien qu'vn de nos mots vous ≈øemble e≈øtre deux, ou trois, ou quatre des vo≈øtres, ≈øelon autant de ≈øyllabes qu'il a. div.head: De la prononciation des langues en general. Of the pronunciation of toungs in generall.

list.label: ET en quoy con≈øi≈øte la prononciation des langues?

list.label: La prononciation des langues con≈øi≈øte en la, vraye & na√Ø≈øue prononciation de toutes les lettres; mais principalement des voyelles, car il n'y a aucune ≈øyll abe qui

item.hi: The pronunciation of toungs doth con≈øi≈øt in the true and liuely pronunciation of all the letters, but namely of the vowelles, for there is not any ≈øyllable, but it

list.label: n'ait vne voyelle au moins, laquelle voyelle donne le ≈øon a la ≈øyllabe, & ≈øans laquelle la ≈øyllabe, ou mot ne ≈ø√ßauroit e≈øtre prononc√©, comme bat, bel, fit, ≈øot, fut, ou vous voyez que le mot bat e≈øt prononc√© par a, bel par e, fit par i, ≈øot par o, fut par u; & que bt ≈øans a, bl ≈øans e, ft ≈øans i, ≈øt ≈øans o, ft ≈øans u, ou quelque autre voyelle, & ain≈øi des autres, ne peuuent auoir aucune prononciation, voire quand toutes les con≈øonantes ≈øeroyent en≈øemble: Mais au contraire vne voyelle ≈øeule peut faired'elle me≈øme vne≈øyllabe, voire vn mot ≈øans l'aide d'aucune con≈øonante, comme y a il, vnir, ou vous voyez que y, a, & u, font trois ≈øyllabes d'eux me≈ømes, & ain≈øi des autres. Mais ce n'e≈øt pas ain≈øi des con≈øonantes. Tellement que qui peut vne fois donner aux voyelles leur vray, & naturel ≈øon, ≈øe peut bien vanter qu'il a atteinct la meilleure part de la pronoÃÑciatioÃÑ, de la langue qu'il apprend: puis que la pronoÃÑciatioÃÑ d'icelle en depeÃÑd entieremeÃÑt.
list.item: hath one vowell at lea≈øt, the which vowell giueth ≈øound to the ≈øyllable, & without which the ≈øyllable or word could not be pronounced, as bat, bel, fit, ≈øot, fut, wherein you may ≈øee that the word bat is pronounced by a, bel by e, fit by i, ≈øot by o, fut by u; & that bt, without a, bl, without e, ft, without i, st, without o, ft, without u, or ≈øome other vowell, and likewi≈øe of other, can not haue any pronunciation, ne when all the con≈øonantes were together: But contrariwi≈øe a vowell alone can make by it ≈øelfe a ≈øyllable, yea a word without the helpe of any con≈øonante, as y a il, vnir, wherein you may ≈øee that y, a, & u, make three ≈øyllables by them ≈øelues, and in like maner of others. But it is not ≈øo of the con≈øonantes. div.head: Pourquoy on e≈øcrit les lettres qui ne ≈øont point prononc√©es. VVherefore Frenchmen do write many letters that are not pronounced.
